ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I did not really know anything about queer or trans history/politics, so this class was eye-opening in many respects.

How to dissect readings, think about the history of queerness, themes of capitalism, race, ability, gender, and their intersection, intersectionality. Largely, learned how to deeply think about readings and historical information.
important histories to queer and trans folk, and you learn the skills to evaluate everyday media through a lens that abstracts from the cis heteronormative agenda.
Understanding of queer histories, writing skills, and delved into the intersection of race, religion and sexuality.
Some topics covered: AIDS epidemic, activit groups like DYKEtactics, ACTUP!, Combache River Collective, capitalism, abolitionist theories, religion,
I learned so much about Queer history and experience along with the AIDs epidemic.

I learned more about the history of queer political movements, coalitions, and identities in the United States over the past half-century, with a very specific focus on intersectionality and bringing to light the work of people who are often neglected by history. We did a lot of close readings of passages and learned to analyze them through specific lenses, with regards to feelings, information, etc.

Research skills, writing skills, critical thinking (through different thought exercises like explicit/implicit, po, concept mapping, etc). We learned so much valuable information about queer and trans histories and politics.
I learned about queer and trans activism history and how it intersects with other identities.
I learned so much about the history of queer liberation and its connection to other social movements.
This is the class that really began to make me start loving learning at Yale. I developed an appreciation for different forms of thinking about societal norms and the history behind them.

Awesome ways to critically evaluate primary sources (different types of writing and documents, artwork). This course also changed how I think about organizing and politics, and revealed to me the multidimensionality of queer and trans politics. I found this course highly engaging and valuable even though I don't identify as gay or queer myself.
I developed critical thinking and analysis skills for looking at source texts, and an understanding of how to have a collaborative discussion space.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class was great. The material was awesome. Sometimes, the class format of discussion-lecture got repetitive by the end of class. I think it could be improved by meeting for only 50 minutes instead of 75 minutes.

strengths- each class was very engaging and the discussion was fun 

weaknesses- felt like only the same people were willing to engage in class

could be improved by breaking into groups to discuss things kinda like how we do in section,

This class was listed as a lecture when in reality it was more of a constant class discussion. The class was definitely set up for student learning and participation, I just wish it wasn't listed as simply a lecture course.  

strengths: section was always very helpful with Jorge, love the content in class and consistently found it engaging.

Strengths: Prof Ferguson and the TAs were so great! They actually just want to you to learn and engage with the material and care less about structured grades and stuff. They are very understanding and flexible and the material is so interesting. Our class had great conversations and Prof Ferguson would tell us really cool stories about his life. 

Weakness: not a big thing but I think it would be helpful to more structure to our assignments, like a rubric or something

The readings are very interesting and manageable; there isn't much work outside of class, and Dr. Ferguson is really engaging. I think it would be cooler if we could have more discussions between students so it would be more of a seminar format than a mini lecture.

I genuinely cannot think of any weaknesses. It is an absolutely amazing course and I'm so thankful I was able to get a spot in it. The workload is manageable, every single lecture is incredibly engaging, class discussions were always helpful for better understanding the material, the readings were interesting, participation was accessible (often giving us a moment to gather our thoughts before we had to speak more), and I learned so much!! 

I've been lucky enough to have taken a lot of great classes at Yale but I think this is the first time I've been able to mark a class as excellent with absolutely no hesitation.
i loved the readings and info but i felt there could have been less of a focus on close reading and more broad discussion

The course has extremely interesting content and a great teaching staff. The course load is also not very difficult, and we read a lot of the passages together in class so its not very overwhelming. I really was pushed out of my comfort zone and enjoyed the content. 

The only weakness of this course is that you arent held very accountable, so its important to motivate yourself to turn everything in on time.

Strengths: Professor Ferguson and the TAs genuinely want you to learn and make class very low stress and engaging to participate in. The assignments for this course are also incredibly easy and build up to your final project. The final project is also an assignment that shouldnt take long to complete because youve worked on it all semester.

No weaknesses!

This class would be amazing as a seminar instead of a lecture. However, the small size of the lecture made it seminar-adjacent, which I think is a huge strength of the class. Prof Ferguson allows each class to run on student input, but every input is followed by his knowledge as he expands the idea someone introduces. It is so obvious how knowledgeable he is, and I love so much how he helps me learn by introducing me to concepts he is an expert on.

Strengths: Prof Ferguson is awesome, TA Kevin is awesome, the assignments very helpfully cumulate to the final project, well balanced workload, super interesting class discussions and readings, excellent project feedback from Kevin. Extremely welcoming and supportive learning environment. Prof Ferguson literally just espouses wisdom that I am grateful to listen to during the entire class. When we did two weeks of virtual classes, anytime I had to use the washroom I would bring my laptop with me and sit it outside the bathroom door so I could keep listening and not miss one word of Prof Ferguson's lecture.

This is an excellent course. The strengths are certainly the vibrant in-class discussions as well as the welcoming and collaborative environment. I think one thing that could be improved slightly is the clarity factor- it was sometimes vague what our assignments were. I also think if the class were organized into themed units that would be helpful to connect parts of the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are curious about any of the topics in this class, take it.
Yes definitely! A great course with a great instructor that will teach you how to think critically. Not too much work, but lots of opportunities for discussion, thinking, and learning
Yessssssssss, this class was spectacular.  You have to take it to really grasp its realness. Ferguson is a helluva professor as well.
Yes.
yes
Yes definitely take it if you can!! There's not a lot of work so it makes a really great 5th class.
Yes, very much
Absolutely!!!

1000%!!! I marked this course as relatively less coursework than other Yale classes--not because it doesn't give enough work, but because other classes I've taken have given too much work and we've kind of just had to accept that as the normal. This class understands that true learning is not simply about how many papers you have to turn in or how many readings you have to do. This class allows you to engage profoundly with each reading, making every single moment a learning experience. Assignments and class discussions ask you to think critically and to think creatively. Professor Ferguson and the TFs are so knowledgeable and they create such a welcoming learning environment. HIGHLY recommend this class, even if (and honestly, *especially if*) you have no prior knowledge on the subject--complex topics are made accessible and it's genuinely an engaging course.
Yes, this is one of the best courses I have taken.
Yes!
Yes! It was extremely interesting and I learned a lot about a subject I was fairly unfamiliar with.

100%. This course teaches queer history in the U.S. from Stonewall to the 2000s in such an informative and engaging way. If youre queer or want to learn more about queer history in the U.S., I definitely recommend this class. If you also need a low workload class thats interesting, I highly recommend! This was one of my favorite classes I took this semester.

Absolutely. I'm grateful I took this class before taking a WGSS (or other subject) seminar because it helped me begin to feel comfortable voicing my thoughts and opinions. This class made me feel valued but it also kept me aware of how much I had yet to learn. It made me feel excited to engage with these new topics.
Absolutely.

I really enjoyed this class. The environment is very laid back but also I learned a great deal about queer and trans social movements. I think we need more courses like this at Yale, that really allow students to learn and be creative without worrying about needlessly competitive academics.
